findings.group_description: The system cannot automatically calculate and adjust salary based on actual working days (e.g., 26 working days per month standard). When employees work extra days, salary does not automatically increase; when they work fewer days, salary does not automatically decrease proportionally. This requires manual tracking and separate adjustments.
findings.issue_explanation: Client requested automated salary payout where employees are paid full salary for 26 working days, with extra days adding to salary and fewer days reducing it automatically. Support confirmed this is not currently supported in the payroll system and is not easy to implement on the payroll side.
findings.limitation_statement: The current payroll system cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally based on actual working days without manual intervention.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks automated, attendance-driven salary calculation that adjusts compensation in real-time based on working days variance from the standard threshold.

findings.group_description: Workflows cannot be used to automate salary proration based on working days. The support team indicated this feature cannot be implemented via workflows, leaving no built-in automation path for attendance-based salary adjustments.
findings.issue_explanation: Client asked if this automation could be implemented via workflows. Support response confirmed it is not something easy to implement on the payroll side and workflows are not a viable solution for this use case.
findings.limitation_statement: Workflows do not support automated salary proration logic based on working days calculations.
findings.gap_statement: There is no workflow-based automation capability for attendance-driven salary adjustments.

findings.group_description: Users are confused when daily wage formulas differ between leave policy and payroll settings. The system intentionally allows payroll-side daily wage calculator to override leave policy formulas for unpaid leave, but this override mechanism is not clearly communicated, causing users to expect formula synchronization.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket reports that the daily wage formula shown in leave policy differs from the formula configured in payroll settings. The user expected these to be synchronized or reflected consistently. The system is working as designed—payroll settings override leave policy—but the UX does not clearly indicate this precedence rule.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform lacks clear visual communication about formula override mechanisms. Users cannot easily understand why formulas are greyed out or how payroll settings supersede leave policy configurations.
findings.gap_statement: There is no synchronized mechanism for daily wage formula configuration between leave policy and payroll modules. The system requires manual alignment and does not provide automatic formula inheritance or synchronization.

findings.group_description: When a new salary configuration is created after an unpaid leave request has been submitted, the system fails to automatically recalculate pending unpaid leave deduction amounts. The deduction remains based on the previous salary configuration, resulting in incorrect payroll deduction amounts.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents a specific case where an employee (Manu Chandran) took 21 days unpaid leave in March 2024. The expected deduction based on the current salary configuration (5250/30.41)*21 = AED 3,625.4, but the actual deduction shown was AED 3,383.76. Development team confirmed that the deduction was calculated based on the employee's previous salary configuration because the latest salary config had not been created by the time the unpaid leave was created. The system failed to update pending unpaid leave deduction amounts when a new salary configuration was subsequently created.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot automatically recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when salary configurations change after leave request creation. Pending leave deductions remain locked to the salary configuration that existed at the time of leave request submission.
findings.gap_statement: There is a product gap in dynamic salary configuration handling—specifically the absence of automatic recalculation of pending leave deductions when salary configurations are updated after leave request submission.

findings.group_description: The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator fails to recognize leap years when computing total service days. For 2024 (a leap year), the system counts 365 days instead of 366 days, resulting in incorrect service period calculations and underpayment of gratuity benefits.
findings.issue_explanation: When calculating EOS gratuity for employee Nabil Kachlan (joining 09/11/2023, exit 08/07/2025), the system computed 607 total service days instead of the correct 608 days. The error stems from the system using 365 days for 2024 (a leap year with 366 days). This caused the service period to be calculated as 1.6630 years instead of 1.6657 years, resulting in a gratuity amount of AED 10,476.98 instead of the correct AED 10,494.24 (verified by MOHRE).
findings.limitation_statement: The platform's gratuity calculation logic does not automatically adjust for leap years, causing inaccurate service period calculations and potential underpayment of employee benefits.
findings.gap_statement: The EOS gratuity calculator lacks dynamic leap year handling. The system requires enhancement to automatically recognize and incorporate 366-day years in service period computations.

findings.group_description: End of Service pro-rated amount calculations produce consistently lower amounts due to decimal precision errors. The system shows amounts less than expected by 0.1 to 0.2 decimals (e.g., 89,999.9 instead of 9000), affecting all employees regardless of departure date.
findings.issue_explanation: The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but the calculation engine has a decimal precision limitation that causes systematic undercalculation of pro-rated amounts when computing final settlements for employees leaving mid-month.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform's current daily wage calculation engine cannot accurately compute pro-rated amounts without decimal precision errors. The system consistently produces amounts that are less than expected by small decimal increments.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks enhanced rounding and decimal handling mechanisms to ensure exact financial calculations in pro-rated salary computations.

findings.group_description: Admin observed a discrepancy between system-calculated EOS gratuity (AED 231,821.10) and manual calculation (AED 252,485) for an employee with service duration of 18 years, 3 months, 17 days. The support team confirmed the system calculation is correct based on the documented gratuity formula (21 days per year for years 1-5, 30 days per year for years 5+), indicating the admin's manual calculation methodology differed from the system's implementation.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents a gratuity calculation verification case where the system applies a tiered daily wage formula: daily wage (salary/30) × 21 days × 5 years for the first 5 years of service, plus daily wage × 30 days × remaining years (with partial years prorated by dividing days by 365). The admin's manual calculation produced a different result, but support confirmed the system's approach is correct.

findings.group_description: For employees departing mid-month, leave days accrued under monthly accrual policies are not included in EOS calculations because the accrual policy only grants leave at the end of the completed month. An employee departing on 17/10/2025 does not receive October leave accrual since the month was not completed, even though the employee worked part of October.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket reveals that monthly accrual policies grant leave days only after the employee completes the full month. Since the employee's departure date (17/10/2025) is mid-month, no October leave days are accrued or included in the EOS gratuity calculation. This is documented as standard system behaviour across all modules. The admin requested that this be changed, but support clarified this is a policy-driven limitation, not a bug.
findings.limitation_statement: Monthly accrual policies do not prorate or include partial month leave balances for mid-month departures. The system cannot automatically grant leave for incomplete months under monthly accrual policies.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks automatic handling of partial month leave accrual for mid-month departures; manual adjustment is required as a workaround.

findings.group_description: Gratuity calculation may not transparently account for leap year days (e.g., Feb 29) when computing total service duration. Users are uncertain whether the system includes or excludes leap year days, leading to discrepancies between manual calculations and platform results.
findings.issue_explanation: Client calculated 913 days of service (including Feb 29, 2024 leap day) resulting in gratuity of AED 14,708.05, but the platform showed 912 days and AED 14,691.95. Investigation revealed the system calculated 14,700 correctly, but the client manually edited it to 14,691.95. The core issue is lack of transparency in how leap year days are handled in service duration calculation.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform does not transparently document or clearly communicate how leap year days are included in service duration calculations for gratuity computation.
findings.gap_statement: There is no clear, user-facing explanation of gratuity calculation methodology, including how leap years, departure dates, and service duration are computed. Users lack transparent documentation about the system's day-counting logic.

findings.group_description: Confusion exists about whether the departure date counts as a working day in service duration calculation. This ambiguity leads to discrepancies: clients may count 93 days (Jan 31 + Feb 29 + Mar 31 + Apr 2) while the system counts 92 days, affecting total service days and gratuity amount.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket states: 'The day of departure is also considered as the last working day of the employee.' However, users are unclear about this rule, leading to manual recalculations that differ from the platform's result. The system counted 912 days while the client expected 913 days based on their interpretation of day-counting methodology.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not clearly communicate the rule that the departure date counts as the last working day, causing user confusion and manual override of calculated amounts.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation is needed to clarify the departure date counting rule and how it affects total service duration in gratuity calculations.

findings.group_description: The platform allows users to manually edit gratuity amounts without validation or warning, enabling accidental overrides of system-calculated values. In this case, the client edited the system-calculated amount (14,700) to 14,691.95, obscuring the actual calculation discrepancy.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket reveals that the system calculated gratuity as 14,700, but the client manually edited it to 14,691.95. This manual override capability masked the real issue and created confusion about whether the system's calculation was correct. No validation or confirmation dialog prevented the edit.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform allows unrestricted manual editing of gratuity amounts without validation, confirmation dialogs, or audit trails to track changes.
findings.gap_statement: There is no validation mechanism or user confirmation step when manually editing gratuity amounts, and no clear audit trail to distinguish system-calculated vs. manually-edited values.

findings.group_description: The gratuity calculation for service periods above 5 years uses a leap year-aware divisor (366 vs 365) when calculating partial year durations. This methodology differs from manual calculation approaches and is not transparently documented, causing confusion about the expected calculation logic.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket reports a gratuity calculation mismatch where Bayzat calculated AED 80,203.28 while the client calculated AED 80,114.75. The difference stems from how incomplete final years are handled: the system counts 339 days for the incomplete year above 5 years and divides by 366 (leap year divisor) to get 0.926 years, whereas the client divided 1434 days by 366 to get 3.9180 years. The system's approach treats completed years separately from the incomplete final year, applying leap year logic only to the partial period.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform's gratuity calculation methodology for partial years and leap year handling is not transparently communicated to users, leading to discrepancies between manual calculations and system output.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation and user-facing explanation of the gratuity calculation logic is insufficient. Users need clear, worked examples showing how service duration is segmented, how partial years are calculated, and when leap year divisors (366) vs standard divisors (365) are applied.

findings.group_description: The platform uses a fixed divisor of 30 days to calculate daily wage (Basic Salary / 30), which cannot be modified via configuration. This prevents organizations that require alternative formulas like (Basic Salary × 12 / 365) from customizing their gratuity calculation methodology.
findings.issue_explanation: In the gratuity calculation for employee Harpreet Lalwani, the platform calculated daily wage as AED 7,500 / 30 = AED 250. The client expected the formula (Basic × 12 / 365) = AED 246.57 instead. Investigation confirmed that the 30-day divisor is hardcoded and cannot be modified by daily wage calculation settings in the configuration page.
findings.limitation_statement: The daily wage calculation mechanism uses a fixed divisor of 30 days and cannot be configured to alternative formulas such as (Basic Salary × 12 / 365).
findings.gap_statement: The platform lacks flexibility in gratuity calculation methods, specifically in daily wage computation. Different organizations may have varying calculation methodologies that cannot currently be accommodated.

findings.group_description: The gratuity calculation for an employee showed 623 days instead of the expected 622 days (after deducting 10 days unpaid leave from 632 total working days). This one-day discrepancy affects the final gratuity amount calculation.
findings.issue_explanation: For employee Harpreet Lalwani (joining 16/09/2022, departure 08/06/2024), the breakdown was: 107 + 365 + 160 = 632 days - 10 days unpaid leave = 622 days expected. However, the platform calculated 623 days, resulting in 623/366 = 1.702 years instead of 622/366 = 1.699 years. This caused the gratuity amount to be AED 8,936.48 instead of the expected AED 8,922.13.

findings.group_description: Leave salary calculations use a fixed divisor from policy configuration (e.g., 30 days) rather than adapting to actual calendar month length (e.g., 31 days). This results in prorated salary amounts that differ from user expectations when the policy divisor does not match the actual number of days in the month.
findings.issue_explanation: Employee Edison Maglanag reported that leave salary for October was calculated using a 30-day divisor when the policy was set to 'calendar days', but October has 31 days. The system calculated 2940 SAR instead of the expected 2988 SAR. Support clarified that the system calculates leave salary based on the daily rate configuration in the leave policy, and the divisor is fixed in policy configuration rather than dynamically adjusted per month.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not dynamically adjust the daily wage divisor based on actual calendar month length; it uses a fixed divisor configured in the leave policy.
findings.gap_statement: Documentation and UI transparency around how daily wage divisor configuration affects leave salary calculations across different month lengths is insufficient, leading to user confusion about expected vs. actual amounts.

findings.group_description: When the daily wage calculator's leave encashment is configured to 'working days', the daily wage rate fluctuates based on the number of working days in each month. This causes cumulative leave salary accrual amounts to vary unpredictably across months with different working day counts, making accrual reporting inconsistent.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket reports that for employee Hussein Ali Tawfik, the cumulative leave salary accrual jumped from an expected 31,610.68 AED (27,013 + 4,596.71) to 34,312 AED in February. The root cause is that the daily wage calculator's leave encashment setting is configured to 'working days', which resulted in 20 working days for February. Since February has fewer working days than January, the daily wage rate changes, causing the accrual amount to differ from the expected cumulative total.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot maintain a stable, consistent daily wage rate for leave accrual calculations when the 'working days' method is selected, because the daily wage denominator changes monthly based on actual working days per month.
findings.gap_statement: The platform lacks a straightforward mechanism to ensure consistent daily wage calculations across months with varying working day counts. Users need a more predictable accrual method that does not fluctuate with monthly working day differences.

findings.group_description: Leave salary and salary proration use independent daily wage configurations with potentially different divisors (e.g., 30 vs 30.42 days). This causes calculation mismatches when clients expect both to use the same formula.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket describes a case where the client configured salary proration as (Basic + allowances / 30.42 days) but leave salary policy uses a separate configuration with a 30-day divisor. For employee Reda taking leave from July 22 - August 20, 2024, the expected proration was (7000/30.42) * 21 = 4,832.35, but the system calculated 4,666.67 because leave salary and salary proration use independent daily wage formulas.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot automatically align leave salary daily wage calculations with salary proration daily wage calculations. These are two separate configuration points that must be manually aligned if consistent calculation is required.
findings.gap_statement: There is no unified daily wage calculation method that consistently applies across both leave salary and salary proration scenarios. The platform lacks a flexible configuration to standardize daily wage calculations across these two features.

findings.group_description: Salary proration calculation is entirely dependent on the employee's assigned work week configuration. When a work week has all 7 days marked as working days with no weekends, the system correctly counts all 31 days as working days, which may appear incorrect to users unfamiliar with their work week setup.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents a support case where a customer reported that proration was calculating based on calendar days instead of working days. Investigation revealed the system was functioning correctly: it calculates based on the work week configuration assigned to the employee. The employee (Melanie Bongalos) was assigned to NVK Operations work week, which has all days configured as working days with no weekend, resulting in 31 working days for the full month.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot automatically detect or override work week configuration; proration is always based on the work week assigned to the employee, regardless of user expectations about what 'working days' should mean.

findings.group_description: When an employee's departure date is set in the future relative to payroll processing, the system fails to prorate salary and displays the full monthly amount instead. This occurs even when the daily wage calculator is configured correctly. The bug was confirmed in the Daria Demo Account and escalated to the development team, where it was subsequently fixed.
findings.issue_explanation: The salary proration logic in the daily wage calculator contains a date-sensitive bug. When processing payroll for an offboarded employee with a future departure date (e.g., Nov 28th) but payroll processed earlier (e.g., Nov 27th), the system does not apply proration and shows the full monthly salary. The system correctly prorates when the departure date is in the past, indicating the logic is conditional on departure date timing relative to processing date.
findings.limitation_statement: The daily wage calculator cannot correctly prorate salaries for employees with departure dates in the future relative to the payroll processing date.
findings.gap_statement: The daily wage calculator lacks robust date-sensitive proration logic that handles dynamic scenarios where departure dates differ from payroll processing dates.

findings.group_description: When an unpaid leave transaction is deleted to recalculate with a new daily wage configuration, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. This results in incorrect payroll data and requires manual intervention to resolve.
findings.issue_explanation: After approving an unpaid leave request and submitting the transaction, if the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction is deleted to recalculate, the system generates two deductions for the same leave request instead of replacing the old one with the new one.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not properly handle transaction deletion and recalculation scenarios; it creates duplicate deductions rather than replacing the old deduction with a recalculated one.
findings.gap_statement: There is a gap in leave-to-payroll transaction management logic that prevents proper handling of leave transaction modifications and recalculations without creating duplicate entries.

findings.group_description: When an unpaid leave request is deleted entirely, the associated payroll deduction persists in the payroll deduction module. This creates orphaned deductions that are no longer tied to any leave request, causing data inconsistency.
findings.issue_explanation: Even after deleting the unpaid leave request completely, the unpaid leave deduction remains in the payroll deductions. Attempting to move the leave request to pending or accepted status does not resolve the persistence of the deduction.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not automatically remove payroll deductions when the associated unpaid leave request is deleted, leaving orphaned deductions in the payroll module.
findings.gap_statement: There is a synchronization gap between the leave management and payroll deduction systems that prevents automatic cleanup of deductions when leave requests are removed.

findings.group_description: Changing the status of an unpaid leave request (e.g., moving from approved to pending or accepted) does not trigger synchronization with the payroll deduction module. Deductions created under the previous status remain unchanged.
findings.issue_explanation: When attempting to move a leave request back to pending or accepted status after recalculation, the system does not update or remove the associated payroll deductions, indicating a lack of bidirectional synchronization between leave and payroll modules.
findings.limitation_statement: Status changes to unpaid leave requests do not automatically reconcile or update associated payroll deductions.

findings.group_description: When public holidays are added after an unpaid leave request is created, the daily wage calculation (performed by Payroll module) and the number of leave days (calculated by Time Off module) become out of sync. This results in incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected by the system.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket documents a case where an employee's unpaid leave deduction for July 2025 was calculated as 3,557.69 AED instead of the expected full month salary of 3,700 AED. Investigation revealed that public holidays (July 23 Revolution Day and June 30 Revolution) were added on 22 July and 25 June respectively, after the leave request was created. The daily wage was calculated when there were 26 working days (1 PH), but by the time leave days were counted, there were 25 working days (2 PHs), causing the mismatch: daily wage = 3,700/26 = 142.31, but applied to 25 days = 3,557.69 AED.
findings.limitation_statement: The system cannot recalculate unpaid leave deductions retroactively when public holiday configuration changes occur after the leave request has been processed. The daily wage calculation is locked at the time of initial computation and does not update when the working days count changes due to late public holiday additions.
findings.gap_statement: The Time Off module does not send complete leave request details to the Payroll module at calculation time, preventing the Payroll module from determining the correct number of working days. A feature enhancement is needed where Time Off module communicates full leave request context to Payroll, ensuring consistent daily wage calculations across configuration changes.

findings.group_description: The Payroll and Time Off modules operate independently without real-time data synchronization. When configuration changes (such as public holiday additions) occur after a leave request is created, the modules calculate using different snapshots of the working days configuration, leading to inconsistent deduction amounts.
findings.issue_explanation: The ticket's investigation notes state: 'the quickest solution is to create a manual deduction' and 'the only one we have is to add manual deduction, or to open all previous cycles until the time of creation of this leave request.' The team confirmed that 'the Time Off module does not send complete leave request details to the Payroll module,' which is why the Payroll side cannot determine the correct number of days when public holidays are added after calculation.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not automatically synchronize leave request details between Time Off and Payroll modules, preventing the Payroll module from recalculating deductions when working days configuration changes.
findings.gap_statement: A long-term feature enhancement is needed where the Time Off module sends all leave request details to the Payroll module, allowing accurate working days determination and consistent salary deduction calculations regardless of when public holidays are configured.

findings.group_description: The unpaid leave deduction calculation uses a configured custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) rather than calendar days, which can result in deduction amounts that exceed the employee's monthly salary. This creates user confusion when the calculated deduction does not match expected amounts.
findings.issue_explanation: The system calculates unpaid leave deductions by dividing the monthly salary by the configured divisor (30.42 custom days) to determine daily wage, then multiplying by the number of leave days in the month. For the employee Facundo Maria Cordero with a 4,300 AED monthly salary and 31 days of unpaid leave in July, the system calculated: 4,300 ÷ 30.42 = 141.35 daily wage × 31 days = 4,381.99 AED deduction. The user expected the deduction to be exactly 4,300 AED (the full monthly salary) to bring the payout to zero, but the custom divisor produced an additional 81.99 AED.
findings.limitation_statement: The system does not cap unpaid leave deductions at the monthly salary amount and does not automatically zero-out payroll when an employee takes unpaid leave for an entire month. The deduction calculation is strictly formula-based using the configured divisor, which may produce amounts exceeding the monthly salary.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks transparent, user-friendly documentation or UI guidance explaining why unpaid leave deductions calculated using custom day divisors may not match monthly salary amounts, and there is no built-in mechanism to alert users when deductions exceed expected values.

findings.group_description: The remarks field in unpaid leave deduction displays an incorrect number of days (31 instead of 29 for February), even though the underlying calculation is mathematically correct. This creates user confusion about the daily rate calculation.
findings.issue_explanation: For February with calendar days configured, the system calculates the correct daily rate (28,700/29 = 989.66) and applies it correctly to the deduction (989.66 × 17 = 16,824.14). However, the remarks field displays 925.81, which is based on 31 days, misrepresenting the calculation basis to the user.
findings.limitation_statement: The remarks field does not dynamically detect the actual number of days in the current month; it appears to default to 31 days regardless of the month selected.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks a mechanism to automatically adjust remarks display based on the actual calendar days in each month, particularly for edge cases like February in leap years.

findings.group_description: Global unpaid leave daily rate configuration automatically overrides policy-level calculation settings. When both exist, the global setting takes precedence, preventing policy-specific customization of leave deduction calculations.
findings.issue_explanation: Ticket TSSD-1753 reports that unpaid leave deductions were calculated using gross salary instead of the configured basic salary divided by working days. Dev team confirmed this is expected behaviour due to a global daily rate configuration that supersedes policy-level settings. The system hierarchy prioritizes global configuration over individual policy configurations.
findings.limitation_statement: The platform cannot apply policy-level customization of unpaid leave deduction calculations when a global daily rate configuration exists. Users cannot override the global setting at the policy level.
findings.gap_statement: The system lacks transparent configuration hierarchy documentation and user controls to allow policy-level customization when global settings exist. There is no mechanism to override global daily rate settings at the policy level.

findings.group_description: The system displays the daily rate from the payroll processing month instead of the leave occurrence month, causing confusion for users. While the deduction amount is calculated correctly, the displayed daily rate does not match the month when leave actually occurred.
findings.issue_explanation: In the reported case, unpaid leave occurred in April with a daily rate of 235.29 (4000 / 17 working days). However, the system displayed the May daily rate of 173.91 (4000 / 23 working days) because the deduction was created in the May payroll cycle. The deduction amount (2,117.65) was correct, but the displayed daily rate created confusion.
findings.limitation_statement: The system recalculates and displays the daily rate based on the payroll processing month rather than storing and displaying the rate from the original leave occurrence month.
findings.gap_statement: A mechanism is needed to preserve and display the initially calculated daily rate at the time of leave request, ensuring the displayed rate reflects the leave occurrence month, not the payroll processing month.

troubleshooting.group_description: When automated working days-based salary calculation is not available, a manual workaround exists using a combination of unpaid leaves and overtime tracking.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Use a mix of unpaid leaves and overtime, tracked separately for each employee. This requires manual configuration and monitoring per employee rather than system-level automation.

troubleshooting.group_description: When a leave policy formula appears greyed out, it indicates that the formula is being overridden by payroll settings. Users can identify which formula is actually in effect by checking the greyed-out state.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: When creating unpaid leave in a leave policy, if the daily wage formula appears greyed out, this indicates the formula configured in payroll settings (Settings > Payroll > Daily Wage Calculation) is overriding the leave policy formula. To verify which formula applies, check the payroll settings configuration. The greyed-out display is an indicator that the payroll-side daily wage calculator takes precedence for unpaid leave deductions.

troubleshooting.group_description: When unpaid leave deductions are calculated based on outdated salary configurations and the deduction has not yet been processed in payroll, users can manually correct the deduction by deleting the leave request and creating it again.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Delete the leave request and create it again if the deduction has not been processed yet. This forces the system to recalculate the deduction using the current salary configuration.

troubleshooting.group_description: End of Service pro-rated amount calculation was producing incorrect amounts with decimal precision errors. The issue was escalated to the development team and subsequently resolved.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Escalate to development team for investigation and fix. Issue has been resolved; verify by recalculating End of Service amounts for affected employees and confirming amounts now match expected values.

troubleshooting.group_description: When leave accrual for the departure month is not automatically included due to monthly accrual policy restrictions, the admin can manually adjust the EOS balance in the EOS section to account for incomplete month leave.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: If the employee's departure month leave balance is not included in the EOS calculation due to monthly accrual policy, the admin can manually adjust the EOS balance in the EOS section to add the missing leave days or their equivalent value.

troubleshooting.group_description: To enable daily leave accrual instead of monthly accrual, which would include partial month leave for mid-month departures, the admin can configure the leave policy as a conditional accrual policy.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Set the leave policy to conditional accrual instead of monthly accrual. Conditional accrual policies grant leave days daily, which means employees departing mid-month will have leave accrued for the days worked in the departure month, automatically including those days in the EOS calculation.

troubleshooting.group_description: When gratuity amounts appear incorrect, verify the system's day-counting methodology and confirm whether the departure date is included as a working day.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Understand that the platform uses a fixed daily wage formula (Basic Salary / 30 days) which is hardcoded and cannot be modified via configuration settings. If your organization requires a different daily wage formula such as (Basic Salary × 12 / 365), the current platform implementation does not support this customization. Verify days worked calculation by manually breaking down: total working days minus unpaid leave days, then confirm the years of service calculation (days / 366).

troubleshooting.group_description: When verifying gratuity calculations, the system segments service duration into completed years and incomplete final years. For periods above 5 years, the incomplete final year is counted in days and divided by 366 (if the period includes a leap year) or 365 (if not) to convert to years.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: To understand the gratuity calculation: (1) Segment service duration into periods: first 5 years at 21 days/year, and years above 5 at 30 days/year. (2) For incomplete final years above 5 years, count the exact days in that period (accounting for month lengths). (3) Determine if the period includes a leap year; if yes, divide day count by 366; if no, divide by 365. (4) Multiply the resulting year fraction by 30 days/year and daily wage. (5) Sum all tier amounts for total gratuity. Example: 339 days in incomplete year with leap year = 339/366 = 0.926 years; 0.926 × 30 × 360 (daily wage) = AED 42,403.27.

troubleshooting.group_description: User expected leave salary to be calculated using 31 days (October calendar days) but system used 30 days. Root cause: the daily rate divisor in the leave policy configuration was set to 30, not 31.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Verify the daily rate configuration in the leave policy. Check the 'Calculation Method' setting (calendar days, working days, or custom days) and confirm the divisor value matches the intended calculation basis. The leave salary calculation follows the policy configuration exactly; if the divisor is 30, the daily wage will be divided by 30 regardless of actual month length.

troubleshooting.group_description: When leave salary accrual amounts vary unexpectedly across months due to differing working day counts, the issue stems from the 'working days' setting in the daily wage calculator's leave encashment configuration.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Navigate to the daily wage calculator's leave encashment settings and change the calculation method from 'working days' to 'custom days'. This will provide a consistent daily wage calculation that does not fluctuate based on the number of working days in each month.

troubleshooting.group_description: When leave salary calculations do not match salary proration calculations, the root cause is independent daily wage configurations using different divisors.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Verify that both the leave salary policy daily wage formula and the salary proration daily wage formula are configured with the same divisor (e.g., both use 30.42 days or both use 30 days). If they differ, manually update the leave salary policy configuration to match the salary proration configuration, or vice versa, depending on client preference.

troubleshooting.group_description: When salary proration appears to be calculating incorrectly based on working days, the root cause is typically the employee's assigned work week configuration.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Verify the employee's assigned work week configuration. Check whether the work week has weekends configured as non-working days. If all 7 days are marked as working days (as in NVK Operations work week), then the full month will correctly count as working days. This is expected behavior based on the work week configuration, not a system error.

troubleshooting.group_description: When salary proration fails for employees with future departure dates, the issue was resolved by the development team through a bug fix.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: The bug affecting future departure date proration has been fixed by the development team. Users should verify that salary proration now correctly applies based on the departure date regardless of whether the departure date is in the past or future relative to payroll processing.

troubleshooting.group_description: When unpaid leave deductions persist after deleting the leave request, manual intervention is required to remove the orphaned deductions from the payroll module.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: After deleting an unpaid leave request, manually locate and remove the associated deduction from the payroll deduction module. This requires direct access to payroll records and may need backend support if the deduction cannot be removed through the UI.

troubleshooting.group_description: To recalculate an unpaid leave deduction after changing the daily wage calculation, the transaction must be deleted and resubmitted. However, this process may create duplicate deductions that require manual cleanup.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Delete the unpaid leave transaction to trigger recalculation with the new daily wage configuration. After deletion, verify that only one deduction exists for the leave request. If duplicates are created, manually remove the old deduction before resubmitting the transaction.

troubleshooting.group_description: When unpaid leave deduction amounts are incorrect due to public holiday timing mismatches, the system cannot automatically recalculate. The support team recommends applying a manual adjustment to correct the deduction amount.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Create a manual deduction to fix the incorrect leave deduction amount. This is the only practical workaround available in the current system when public holidays are added after leave requests have been processed. The alternative of reopening previous payroll cycles is not recommended as it is impractical.

troubleshooting.group_description: User received an unpaid leave deduction that exceeded their expected amount. The root cause is the configured daily wage divisor in the unpaid leave policy setting.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Verify the unpaid leave policy configuration by checking the daily wage divisor setting. The system uses the configured divisor (e.g., 30.42 custom days) to calculate daily wage: divide monthly salary by the divisor, then multiply by the number of leave days in the month. If the deduction exceeds the monthly salary due to the divisor configuration, manually add an adjustment entry to balance the payroll to the desired net amount (e.g., zero payout for full month absence).

troubleshooting.group_description: When remarks field shows an incorrect daily rate reference, verify the actual deduction amount applied to the payroll to confirm the backend calculation is correct.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Check the actual deduction amount (e.g., 16,824.14 for 17 unpaid days in February) against the correct daily rate calculation (salary ÷ actual calendar days in month). The deduction amount will be accurate even if the remarks field displays the wrong number of days.

troubleshooting.group_description: When unpaid leave deductions appear incorrect despite proper policy configuration, the issue may be caused by a global daily rate configuration overriding policy settings.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: Check the global daily rate configuration for unpaid leaves. The global unpaid leave daily rate setting takes precedence over policy-level calculation methods. Verify that the global configuration aligns with expected deduction calculations before assuming policy-level settings are incorrect.

troubleshooting.group_description: The system was recalculating daily rates on display, showing rates from the payroll month instead of the leave month. This caused confusion even though deduction amounts were correct.
troubleshooting.workaround_or_resolution: A fix was deployed to store the initially calculated daily rate at the time of leave request and display that stored amount on the daily rate label instead of recalculating it each time. This ensures the displayed daily rate reflects the leave occurrence month, not the payroll processing month.
